Our blank in bliss to fill,
Here a star, and there a star,
Here a mist, and there a mist,

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: III. ROUGE ET NOIR.
poem.l: But tens have won an all.

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: IV. ROUGE GAGNE.
poem.l: 'T IS so much joy! 'T is so much joy!
If I should fail, what poverty!
And yet, as poor as I
Have ventured all upon a throw;
Life is but life, and death but death!
Bliss is but bliss, and breath but breath!
At least to know the worst is sweet.
And if I gain, — oh, gun at sea,
Oh, bells that in the steeples be,
For heaven is a different thing

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: V.
poem.l: GLEE! the great storm is over!
How they will tell the shipwreck
Till the children ask, "But the forty?
Did they come back no more?"
Then a silence suffuses the story,
And a softness the teller's eye;
And the children no further question.

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: VI.
poem.l: IF I can stop one heart from breaking,
I shall not live in vain;
If I can ease one life the aching,
I shall not live in vain.

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: VII. ALMOST!
poem.l: I might have chanced that way!

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers

And then the brake is still.
Mirth is the mail of anguish,

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers

poem.l: In just the dress his century wore;
A passage back, or two, to make
To times when he was young.
On what concerns our mutual mind,
When Sappho was a living girl,
As one should come to town
And tell you all your dreams were true:
He lived where dreams were sown.
You beg him not to go;

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: XV. THE LONELY HOUSE.
poem.l: I KNOW some lonely houses off the road
A robber 'd like the look of,—
How orderly the kitchen 'd look by night,
But they could gag the tick,
And so the walls don't tell,
A pair of spectacles afar just stir —
The moon slides down the stair
The sun has got as far
While the old couple, just astir,
Fancy the sunrise left the door ajar!

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: VI.
poem.l: IF you were coming in the fall,

If I could see you in a year,
I'd wind the months in balls,
And put them each in separate drawers,
I'd count them on my hand,
If certain, when this life was out,
That yours and mine should be,

But now, all ignorant of the length

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: XIII. RENUNCIATION.
poem.l: THERE came a day at summer's full
I thought that such were for the saints,
The sun, as common, went abroad,
As if no soul the solstice passed
The time was scarce profaned by speech;
Each was to each the sealed church,
The hours slid fast, as hours will,
So faces on two decks look back,
And so, when all the time had failed,
Sufficient troth that we shall rise—

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: XIV. LOVE'S BAPTISM.
poem.l: I'M ceded, I 've stopped being theirs;
The name they dropped upon my face
With water, in the country church,
And they can put it with my dolls,
My childhood, and the string of spools
But this time consciously, of grace
Called to my full, the crescent dropped,
My second rank, too small the first,
Crowned, crowing on my father's breast,
With will to choose or to reject.
And I choose— just a throne.

poem.l: SOME keep the Sabbath going to church;

And instead of tolling the bell for church,

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers

poem.l: THE bee is not afraid of me,
The pretty people in the woods
The brooks laugh louder when I come,

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: VIII. SUMMER'S ARMIES.
poem.l: SOME rainbow coming from the fair!
Some vision of the world Cashmere
Or else a peacock's purple train,
Feather by feather, on the plain
From some old fortress on the sun
Baronial bees march, one by one,
The robins stand as thick to-day
As flakes of snow stood yesterday,
On fence and roof and twig.
The orchis binds her feather on
For her old lover, Don the Sun,
The regiment of wood and hill

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: IX. THE GRASS.
poem.l: THE grass so little has to do,—
And stir all day to pretty tunes
And hold the sunshine in its lap
And thread the dews all night, like pearls,
And even when it dies, to pass
As lowly spices gone to sleep,
And then to dwell in sovereign barns,
The grass so little has to do,
I wish I were the hay!

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: X.

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: XI. SUMMER SHOWER.
poem.l: A DROP fell on the apple tree,
A half a dozen kissed the eaves,
A few went out to help the brook,
That went to help the sea.
The dust replaced in hoisted roads,
The sunshine threw his hat away,
And bathed them in the glee;
The East put out a single flag,

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: XII. PSALM OF THE DAY.
poem.l: A SOMETHING in a summer's day,
As sIow her flambeaux burn away,
A something in a summer's noon,—
An azure depth, a wordless tune,
And still within a summer's night
I clap my hands to see;
Then veil my too inspecting face,
Lest such a subtle, shimmering grace
The purple brook within the breast
Still rears the East her amber flag,
Guides still the sun along the crag
Like flowers that heard the tale of dews,
But never deemed the dripping prize
Or bees, that thought the summer's name
By tropic hint, — some travelled bird
Or wind's bright signal to the ear,

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: XIII. THE SEA OF SUNSET.
poem.l: THIS is the land the sunset washes,
These are the banks of the Yellow Sea;
Where it rose, or whither it rushes,
Night after night her purple traffic
Strews the landing with opal bales;
Dip, and vanish with fairy sails.

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers
poem.title: XIV. PURPLE CLOVER.
poem.l: THERE is a flower that bees prefer,

She doth not wait for June;
For privilege of sod and sun,

poem.publisher: Boston: Roberts Brothers

These are the days when skies put on

poem.l: DELAYED till she had ceased to know,

Later by just an hour than death, —
Could she have guessed that it would be;
Could but a crier of the glee

poem.title: IV.
poem.l: Untouched by morning and untouched by noon,
Sleep the meek members of the resurrection,
Rafter of satin, and roof of stone.
Light laughs the breeze in her castle of sunshine;
Babbles the bee in a stolid ear;
Pipe the sweet birds in ignorant cadence,—
Grand go the years in the crescent above them;
Worlds scoop their arcs, and firmaments row,

poem.l: HOW many times these low feet staggered,

To know if he was patient, part content,
Was dying as he thought, or different;
Was it a pleasant day to die,
And did the sunshine face his way?

And if he spoke, what name was best,
Till love that was, and love too blest to be,

poem.l: "GOING to him! Happy letter! Tell him —
Tell him the page I did n't write;
Tell him I only said the syntax,
And left the verb and the pronoun out.
Tell him just how the fingers hurried,
Then how they waded, slow, slow, slow;
And then you wished you had eyes in your pages,
So you could see what moved them so.
"Tell him it was n't a practised writer,
You guessed, from the way the sentence toiled;
You could hear the bodice tug, behind you,
As if it held but the might of a child;
You almost pitied it, you, it worked so.
Tell him — No, you may quibble there,
For it would split his heart to know it,
And then you and I were silenter.
"Tell him night finished before we finished,
And the old clock kept neighing 'day!'
And you got sleepy and begged to be ended —
What could it hinder so, to say?
Tell him just how she sealed you, cautious,
But if he ask where you are hid
Gesture, coquette, and shake your head!"

Proud of the pain I did not feel till thee,
Proud of my night since thou with moons dost slake it,
Not to partake thy passion, my humility.

It was the limit of my dream,
I knew no more of want or cold,
For this new value in the soul,
The heaven below the heaven above
Why floods are served to us in bowls, —

poem.l: SPLIT the lark and you'll find the music,
Bulb after bulb, in silver rolled,
Scantily dealt to the summer morning,
Saved for your ear when lutes be old.
Loose the flood, you shall find it patent,
Gush after gush, reserved for you;

poem.title: V. TO MARCH.
poem.l: How out of breath you are!
Oh, March, come right upstairs with me,
I have so much to tell!
I got your letter, and the birds';
That you were coming, — I declare,
You left for me to hue;
You took it all with you.
He stayed away a year, to call
As soon as you have come,
That blame is just as dear as praise
And praise as mere as blame.

poem.publisher: Boston, Mass.: Little, Brown, and Co.
poem.editor: Todd, Mabel Loomis, 1856-1932
poem.title: VI. MARCH.
poem.l: WE like March, his shoes are purple,
Makes he mud for dog and peddler,
Knows the adder's tongue his coming,
Stands the sun so close and mighty
News is he of all the others;

poem.publisher: Boston, Mass.: Little, Brown, and Co.
poem.editor: Todd, Mabel Loomis, 1856-1932
poem.title: VII. DAWN.
poem.l: NOT knowing when the dawn will come

poem.publisher: Boston, Mass.: Little, Brown, and Co.

poem.title: VIII.
poem.l: A MURMUR in the trees to note,
A star not far enough to seek,
A long, long yellow on the lawn,
Not audible, as ours to us,
A hurrying home of little men
All this, and more, if I should tell,
Of robins in the trundle bed
Whose nightgowns could not hide the wings,
But then I promised ne'er to tell;
How could I break my word?
So go your way and I'll go mine, —
No fear you'll miss the road.

poem.publisher: Boston, Mass.: Little, Brown, and Co.
poem.editor: Todd, Mabel Loomis, 1856-1932
poem.title: IX.

poem.title: XIV.A WELL.
poem.l: The grass does not appear afraid;
Can stand so close and look so bold
At what is dread to me.
The sedge stands next the sea,
Where he is floorless, yet of fear
But nature is a stranger yet;
The ones that cite her most
Have never passed her haunted house,
To pity those that know her not
That those who know her, know her less

poem.title: XXI. THE MOON.
poem.l: THE moon was but a chin of gold
And now she turns her perfect face
Her forehead is of amplest blond;
Her eye unto the sumtner dew
Her lips of amber never part;
But what must be the smile
Upon her friend she could bestow
And what a privilege to be
For certainly her way might pass
The stars the trinkets at her belt,

poem.publisher: Boston, Mass.: Little, Brown, and Co.
poem.editor: Todd, Mabel Loomis, 1856-1932
poem.title: XXII. THE BAT.

poem.publisher: Boston, Mass.: Little, Brown, and Co.

poem.title: XXIII. THE BALLOON.
poem.l: YOU've seen balloons set, haven't you?
It is as swans discarded you
Their liquid feet go softly out
They spurn the air as 't were too mean
Their ribbons just beyond the eye,
And yet the crowd applauds below;
The gilded creature strains and spins,
The crowd retire with an oath
The dust in streets goes down,

poem.publisher: Boston, Mass.: Little, Brown, and Co.
poem.editor: Todd, Mabel Loomis, 1856-1932
poem.title: XXIV. EVENING.
poem.l: And workmen finished, one by one,
The low grass loaded with the dew,
The twilight stood as strangers do
With hat in hand, polite and new,
To stay as if, or go.
A vastness, as a neighbor, came, —
A wisdom without face or name,
A peace, as hemispheres at home, —

poem.title: XXVIII. THE COMING OF NIGHT.
poem.l: HOW the old mountains drip with sunset,

How the old steeples hand the scarlet,
Have I the lip of the flamingo
Then, how the fire ebbs like billows,
How a small dusk crawls on the village
And the odd flambeaux no men carry
Now it is night in nest and kennel,
Just a dome of abyss is nodding
These are the visions baffled Guido;

Just a look at the horses —
Put me in on the firmest side,
For we must ride to the Judgment,
But never I mind the bridges,
And never I mind the sea;
By my own choice and thee.
Good-by to the life I used to live,
And the world I used to know;
And kiss the hills for me, just once;
Now I am ready to go!

poem.title: XLIII. JOY IN DEATH.
poem.l: IF tolling bell I ask the cause.
I'm answered in a lonesome tone;
That bells should joyful ring to tell
A soul had gone to heaven,
Would seem to me the proper way
A good news should be given.

poem.title: XLIV.
poem.l: IF I may have it when it's dead
If just as soon as breath is out
Until they lock it in the grave,
For though they lock thee in the grave,
Think of it, lover! I and thee
Permitted face to face to be;
After a life, a death we'll say, —
For death was that, and this is thee.

poem.title: XLVI. DYING.
poem.l: I HEARD a fly buzz when I died;
Was like the stillness in the air
The eyes beside had wrung them dry,
For that last onset, when the king
I willed my keepsakes, signed away
And then the windows failed, and then
I could not see to see.

poem.title: XLVIII.
poem.l: THERE's been a death in the opposite house
I know it by the numb look
The neighbors rustle in and out,
A window opens like a pod,
They wonder if It died on that, —
I used to when a boy.
As if the house were his,
And he owned all the mourners now,
And then the milliner, and the man
To take the measure of the house.
Of tassels and of coaches soon;

poem.title: L. THE SOUL'S STORM.
poem.l: As if the cloud that instant slit
It burned me in the night,
It sickened, fresh upon my sight
I thought that storm was brief, —
But Nature lost the date of this,
And left it in the sky.

poem.title: LVIII. RETROSPECT.
poem.l: 'T WAS just this time last year I died.
I know I heard the corn,
When I was carried by the farms, —
I thought how yellow it would look
And then I wanted to get out,
I thought just how red apples wedged
And carts went stooping round the fields
I wondered which would miss me least,
And if my stocking hung too high,
Would it blur the Christmas glee,
That not a Santa Claus could reach
But this sort grieved myself, and so
I thought how it would be
When just this time, some perfect year,
